editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.head: THE Introductory Epi≈øtle, Pre≈øented to the RIGHT HONOURABLE WILLIAM, Lord Craven, Baron Craven OF HAMSTEAD MARSH.
div.p:
THE extraordinary Character you have acquir ‚Ä¢ d by the joint Con≈øent of tho≈øe that have the Honour of your Acquaintance, Encourages me to deviate from the common Road, u≈øed by our Modern Authors; being made ≈øufficiently ≈øen≈øible, how much a
Mind endow'd with Genorous and Mode≈øt Inclinations (the in≈øeparable Companions of a Great Soul) di≈ødains the ful≈øome Prai≈øes, which tho≈øe Gentlemen make the Chief Subject of their Dedications, whenever they pretend to Court the Patronage of Per≈øons of Quality, in behalf of their Treati≈øes. I mu≈øt confe≈øs, I ≈øhould ≈øcarce have had ≈øo much Pre≈øumption thus to intrude my ≈øelf into your Lord≈øhip's Favour, if I had not been ≈øufficiently per≈øuaded, that the Renown our Author has ≈øo de≈øervedly gain ‚Ä¢ d both here and abroad (and that under the Protection of ≈øome of the greate≈øt Princ ‚Ä¢ s in Europe) would be prevailing enough with your Lord≈øhip, to pardon an Undertaking, which, if in it ≈øelf ju≈øtifiable in nothing el≈øe, might perhaps claim the benefit of a general Cu≈øtom from your Goodne≈øs. The Reputation of our Author being ≈øo univer≈øally and unque≈øtionably e≈øtabli≈øhed
among all ≈øuch as have a true reli≈øh of Learning, I might without the lea≈øt Prejudice to him, ≈øupercede to enlarge here upon this Treati≈øe, if it were not rather out of a de≈øire to ≈øatisfie the Curio≈øity of ≈øome, who beleive to have ≈øufficient Rea≈øon for certain Objections made again≈øt ≈øome A≈ø≈øertions contained in this Treati≈øe, than with an Intention to make the lea≈øt Addition to a Piece, which, whether in regard of the nicety of the Subject it Treats of, or of the Concatination and force of its Arguments, de≈øerves to be reckoned among the be≈øt now extant in Europe. Tho≈øe, who center the utmo≈øt Felicity of Civil Society in a Democratical form of Government, have not been wanting to charge our Author with too much Pa≈ø≈øion for that Doctrine, of Pa≈ø≈øive Obedience, which leaves Subjects to the ab≈øolute Di≈øpo≈øal of their Princes; But, be≈øides that, the Appendix annexed to
this Treati≈øe, written by our Author, in oppo≈øition to Mr. Hobbes's Mon≈øtrous Principles concerning this unlimited Power, may ≈øufficiently clear him from this Imputation; If the≈øe Gentlemen would have taken the pains to make a due compari≈øon of the ≈øeveral Pa≈ø≈øages both in this, and other Treati≈øes of our Author, relating to this Subject, they might, without much difficulty, have been convinc ‚Ä¢ d of their Error; As far as I am capable of penetrating into the Matter, it is the word Princeps, or Prince, which ≈øticks mo≈øt clo≈øely in their Stomachs, not con≈øidering, That the Words, Summi Imperantes, or Sovereigns; and that of Princeps, or Prince, are Synoms to our Author; and that out of a great many Pa≈ø≈øages in this Treati≈øe, it is ≈øufficiently apparent, that he attributes the Sovereign Power not always to one ≈øingle Per≈øon, but ≈øometimes
al≈øo to a Council inve≈øted with the Supream Admini≈øtration of the Sovereign Authority in the Commonwealth. If it were but only for that Advice given by our Author at the very beginning of his Appendix to young Lawyers, to wit, to take care, that under the Pretence of maintaining the Prerogatives of Princes, they ≈øhould not be prodigal of their Liberty and Property, and his a≈ø≈øerting the Foundation of Civil Societies to be built upon the Common Con≈øent of mutual Defence again≈øt Violences; This alone, I ≈øay, might be a convincing Argument to any unbya≈øs'd Per≈øon, that his Aim was very remote from maintaining an Arbitrary Power in the State, The next thing laid to our Author's Charge is, that he ≈øo entirely ≈øeparates the Chri≈øtian Religion from the State, as not to have the lea≈øt Interference with one another; whereas the contrary is now
a-days practi≈øed in mo≈øt Chri≈øtian Sta ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ s, and in the Commonwealth of the Jews (in≈øtituted by God‚ñ™s peculiar Direction) this Union was in≈øeparable. It cannot be denied, but that the outward Form of Church Government, e≈øpecially among the Prote≈øtants, is in a great mea≈øure, and in mo≈øt places adapted to that of the State; it being evident, that mo≈øt of the Monarchical States, Epi≈øcopacy, as mo≈øt ≈øuitable with that Con≈øtitution, was never aboli≈øhed; as on the contrary, the ≈øame was quite extirpated in the Prote≈øtant Commonwealths. This is mo≈øt particularly ob≈øervable among the Lutherans, who, tho' all agreeing in Point of Doctrine, are neverthele≈øs, ≈øo far different from one another in the Ceremonial Point, and outward Form of Church Government, that in outward Appearance, they ≈øeem'd to be ≈øo many ≈øeveral Churches. Thus in the two Northern
Kingdoms of Sweden and Denmark, the Epi≈øcopal Authority (tho' much dimini≈øhed in its Revenues) is retained to this day; whereas in ≈øome Commonwealths in Germany, where the ≈øame Religion is E≈øtabli≈øhed, it is quite aboli≈øhed, and not the lea≈øt foot≈øteps of Subordination of Prie≈øts to be met with. But this Objection is ea≈øily cleared, if we take into due Con≈øideration, that it being the Intention of our Author to repre≈øent in tho≈øe places Reliligion in its genuine and native Con≈øtitution, freed from all what is foreign to its true Genius, he did not think it convenient, to clog it with any thing that was not an E≈ø≈øential part of it; e≈øpecially when his chief aim was to ≈øhew the real difference betwixt the Chri≈øtian and Jewi≈øh Religion. There are al≈øo not a few, who prompted by a prepo≈øterous Zeal, have imputed to our Author a certain kind of Libertini≈øm in Religion, for which, I can ≈øee no other Rea≈øon, than that they are di≈ø≈øatisfied with his A≈ø≈øertions again≈øt any thing that has the lea≈øt re≈øemblance of Per≈øecution upon the ≈øcore of Difference of Opinions. I am well ≈øatisfied, that the Rea≈øons alledged by him, are ≈øo ≈øolid in them≈øelves, and ≈øo exactly applied to this Purpo≈øe, that they cannot but be Convincing
to all ≈øuch, as are not prepo≈ø≈ø ‚Ä¢ ≈ø≈øed either with By Intere≈øt, or a mo≈øt stupid Ignorance, For, if the Slavery of the Body be ab≈øolutely repugnant to the Inclinations of a generous Soul, How much more in≈øupportable mu≈øt the Slavery of the Mind be to a ≈øublime Genius, elevated above the common Sphere of bigotted Zealots Ignorance, being the Mother of perverted Zeal, and con≈øequently of a per≈øecuting Spirit, the ≈øame ought to be look'd upon as the common Enemy of all ≈øuch as are guided by the Light of true Rea≈øon? I cannot but take notice here, that our Engli≈øh Modern Clergy has of late gain'd ≈øo peculiar a Character of following ≈øo clo≈øely the≈øe foot≈øteps of convincing ≈øuch as differ from them in Opinion, rather by ≈øtrength of Argument, than any forcible Means, that I do not know whether they are not preferrable in this Point, before any other in Europe. If any one que≈øtions th ‚Ä¢ Truth of it, I appeal to Mr. Toland's Ca≈øe, concerning his Treati≈øe, Entituled, Chri≈øtianity not My≈øterious. It is both beyond my ≈øcope, and the compa≈øs of a Letter, to enter upon the Merits of the Cau≈øe on both Sides, it will be ≈øufficient here to refer my ≈øelf to what has been Publi≈øhed again≈øt him lately here in England,
and in other Places; All which, if duely compared, will ≈øoon evince, how much the Engli≈øh Clergy ‚Ä¢ as out-done the re≈øt, both by force of Argument, and a generous, gentle Behaviour. But I am afraid I have abu≈øed your Lord≈øhip's Patience; I will therefore conclude with recommending both my Author and my Self, to your Lord≈øhip's Protection, begging Leave to ≈øub≈øcribe my ≈øelf,

div.head: OF THE Nature and Qualification OF RELIGION, In REFERENCE to CIVIL SOCIETY, &c.
div.p:
AMong all tho≈øe Que≈øtions, which have for many Ages pa≈øt been Controverted among Chri≈øtians, this may be deem'd one of the Chiefe≈øt, which Treats of the Nature, Authority, and Power of the Church; and which of the ≈øeveral Chri≈øtian Sects ought mo≈øt ju≈øtly to claim the Title of the True Church. The Romanists keep this for their la≈øt Re≈øerve, when Engag'd with the Prote≈øtants, That they Attribute the Name of the True Church only to them≈øelves, and boldly ≈øtigmatize all ≈øuch as are not of their Communion, with the Names of rebellious De≈øerters. This is the main Bulwark they rely upon, thinking it ≈øufficient to Alledge in their own behalf; That they are not obliged ≈øo ≈øtrictly to Examin, and maintain every Article of their
Faith again≈øt the Prote≈øtants; ≈øince, whatever Objections may be made out of the Holy Scripture, the ≈øame ought to be rejected as Erroneous, if not agreeable with the Interpretations and Traditions of their Church; Thus making them≈øelves both Judges and Witne≈ø≈øes in their own Cau≈øe. ‚Ä¢ e≈øides this, it is to be look'd upon as a Matter of the greate≈øt Con≈øequence, both in regard of the Chri≈øtian Church, and the Publick Safety in a State, to know exactly, what bounds ought to be pre≈øcribed to the Prie≈øtly Order in Eccle≈øia≈øtical Affairs; as likewi≈øe to determin, how far the Power of Sovereigns extends it ≈øelf in Eccle≈øia≈øtical Matters: For, if either of them tran≈øgre≈øs their Bounds, it mu≈øt of nece≈ø≈øity prove the Cau≈øe of great Abu≈øes, Di≈øturbances and Oppre≈ø≈øions, both in Church and State. I was the ≈øooner prevail'd upon to Search into the very bottom of this Que≈øtion, at this juncture of Time, when not only the Romi≈øh Prie≈øts apply all their Cunning for the rooting out of the Prote≈øtants, but al≈øo ≈øome of the greate≈øt Princes in Chri≈øtendom (≈øetting a≈øide the Antient way of Converting People by Rea≈øon and force of Arguments) have now recour≈øe to op ‚Ä¢ n Violence; and by Dragooning, force their mi≈øerable Subjects to a Religion, which always appear'd abominable to them. But if we propo≈øe to our ≈øelves to examin this Point, according to its own ≈øolid Principles (as we ought to do) without having recour≈øe to Ambiguous Terms and Tergiver≈øations, it is ab≈øolutely requi≈øite, that we trace the very Original of Religion in General; and of the
Chri≈øtian Religion in Particular, ≈øo as to Examin both their Natural Qualifications in reference to Civil Society. For, if this, which is to be look'd upon as the Foundation Stone, be well Secured: And we afterwards do look into the Scriptures, to inve≈øtigate, in what manner Chri≈øt him≈øelf has repre≈øented his Doctrine to us; it will be no difficult Task to judge, whether, according to the In≈øtitution of our Saviour, there ought to be an Eccle≈øia≈øtical Sovereignty exerci≈øed by Prie≈øts? Or, whether Princes have a Right to make u≈øe of an Ab≈øolute Power? Or can Compel their Subjects to Obedience by Force of Arms, in Matters of Religion?

¬ß. 1. That there is a Supream Being, the Conce ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
ing Rel ‚Ä¢ gion before Civil Societies w ‚Ä¢ r ‚Ä¢ I ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ituted Author and Creator both of the Univer≈øe, and e≈øpecially of Mankind, which ought to be acknowledged and wor≈øhipped as ≈øuch by Menkind, as they are Rational Creatures, has been generally receiv'd, not only among Chri≈øtians, but al≈øo by mo≈øt of the Pagan Philo≈øophers, that to pretend to demon≈øtrate it here, would be Superfluous, and perhaps might be taken as done in prejudice of the judicious Reader; ≈øince, ≈øcarce any body, that is not beyond his right Wits, can be ≈øuppo≈øed, now a days, to make the lea≈øt Doubt of the Verity of this A≈ø≈øertion. The true Knowledge of Divine Wor≈øhip ari≈øes from two ≈øeveral Springs: For, we either by true Ratio ‚Ä¢ ination, deduc ‚Ä¢ d out of the Light of Nature, may be Convinced of tho≈øe Sentiments we ought to have of God, and what Reverence is due to him from us Mortals: Or el≈øe, ≈øome Matters, being beyond
our Apprehen≈øion, by the bare Light of Nature, are by God's ≈øpecial Command Revealed to Mankind. Both Kinds are to be the Subject of the following Treati≈øe; with this Re≈øtriction neverthele≈øs, not to in≈øi≈øt upon each particular Head of either of them, any further, than they have relation to Civil Society.

¬ß. 2. The fir≈øt Thing which is to be con≈øidered, both in Natural and Revealed Religion, Every Man is accountable for his Religion. is, That every body is obliged to wor≈øhip God in his own Per≈øon, Religious Duty being not to be performed by a Deputy, but by him≈øelf, in Per≈øon, who expects to reap the Benefit of religious Wor≈øhip, promi≈øed by God Almighty. For Man, being a rational Creature, owing its Off-≈øpring to God alone, is thereby put under ≈øuch an indi≈øpen≈øible Obligation, that the Co≈øideration of wor≈øhipping him, to the utmo≈øt of his Power, can never be entirely ex≈øtingui≈øhed in a rational Soul. And here lies the main difference betwixt that Care, which, we ought to have our Souls, and that of our Bodies; the latter of which, may be committed to the Management of others, who being to be Accountable for all Injuries, which may befall us under their Tuition, we are thereby freed from any Guilt again≈øt our ≈øelves. So do we commit our ≈øelves, when we pa≈øs the Seas, to the Management of the Ma≈øter of a Ship, by who≈øe ≈øole Care, without our own A≈ø≈øi≈øtance, we are conducted to the de≈øired Port. But, no body can ≈øo entirely t ‚Ä¢ ansfer the Care of his Soul, and the Exerci≈øe of Religious Wor≈øhip from him≈øelf to
another Man, as to make him alone Accountable for all Mi≈øcarriages, and to free him≈øelf from Puni≈øhment. Every one of us ≈øhall give Rom. 14. 12. Rom. 9. 3. Account of him≈øelf to God. And it is in vain for St. Paul to wi≈øh, to be Accur≈øed from Chri≈øt, for his Brethren, his Kin≈ømen, according to the Fle≈øh. And, though it is undeniable, That tho≈øe who have been negligent in taking care of other Peoples Souls, that were committed to their Charge, ≈øhall receive Puni≈øhment; Neverthele≈øs, the≈øe, who≈øe Souls have been thus neglected, ≈øhall peri≈øh with them, for having put too much Tru≈øt in others, and neglected their own Salvation. As it is plainly expre≈ø≈øed by the Prophet Ezekiel, 33. 7, 8. And the Habak. 2. 4. Mark, 16. 16. Ju≈øt ≈øhall live by Faith. And the Evangeli≈øt St. Mark, ≈øpeaks without any Re≈øervation. He that believed not, ≈øhall be damned; without di≈øtinction, whether you were ≈øeduced by others, or whether you have renounced your Faith for worldly Ends.

¬ß. 3. From whence it is evident, That, Religion How the ≈øame is to be exerci≈øed in the free State of Nature. having its relation to God, the ≈øame may be exerci≈øed without the Communion of a great many; And, that a Man ought not to judge of the Soundne≈øs of his Doctrine or Religion, by the Number of tho≈øe that adhere to it. So, that it is manife≈øt, That, at the beginning of the World, our fir≈øt Parents might, and did really perform Religious Duties; And, that, if one alone, or a few together, live in a ≈øolitary Place, they are therefore not to be deem'd to live without Religion, becau≈øe, they do not make up a Congregation. Communion, are no more to be counted Rebels, than our Modern Philo≈øophers are to be taken for Fools and Madmen, becau≈øe they differ in Opinion from Ari≈øtotle. For, all Believers, who adhere to the true Faith, are, in regard of their Head Je≈øus Chri≈øt, of an equal degree, and aim all at the ≈øame End. And Chri≈øt having given this Promi≈øe to all Believers; That where two or three were gathered together Mat. 18. 20. in his Name, there would he be in the mid≈øt of them; no Church can claim any Prerogative by rea≈øon of the number of its Adherents. What the Romani≈øts alledge for them≈øelves out of the Apo≈øtolical Creed, is ≈øo full of ab≈øurdity, that it contradicts it ≈øelf, viz. out of the≈øe words: I believe one Holy, Catholick, and Apo≈øtolical Church; For, except they could cajole us into a belief that the≈øe words imply as much as to ≈øay: There is but one true Church upon Earth, which is the Roman Catholick, there being no other be≈øides that, I cannot ≈øee what Inference can be drawn from thence to their Advantage; Be≈øides, that the very ≈øen≈øe of the words contradict this Interpretation, if Rea≈øon, the Holy Scripture, and Experience it ≈øelf did not ≈øufficiently convince us to the contrary. It is beyond contradiction, that there is but one true Church upon Earth, there being but one God, one Chri≈øt, one Bapti≈øm, and one Faith; But, concerning one Point, many Errors and Abu≈øes may be committed. Neither have the Popi≈øh Party any rea≈øon to brag of a particular Holine≈øs, e≈øpecially concerning the≈øe matters, wherein they differ from the Prote≈øtants. The word Catholick,
relates here to a Doctrine, not to a Sovereign State, who≈øe Authority is to be Univer≈øal over Chri≈øtendom, ≈øo that that Church is to be e≈øteemed a Catholick Church, which contains every particular Point of Doctrine in the true ≈øen≈øe, as they are propo≈øed in the Holy Scripture; And tho≈øe are called Hereticks, who only profe≈øs ≈øome particular Points out of the Holy Writ, (for ≈øuch as ab≈øolutely reject it, are counted Infidels and Reprobates) but either deny, or explain the re≈øt in a wrong and perverted ≈øen≈øe. How can the Popi≈øh Clergy therefore a≈ø≈øume the Title of the Catholick Church, before they have, and that without contradiction, proved every Point of their Faith out of the Holy Scripture? Or, exclude us Prote≈øtants from that Title, till they have proved that our Doctrine is contrary to it? La≈øtly, It is called the Apo≈øtolical Church, as being founded upon the Doctrine of the Apo≈øtles. And the true Church lo≈øes nothing of its intrin≈øick Value, whether it has been planted by the Apo≈øtles, or whether the Apo≈øtolical Doctrine has been tran≈ømitted to them by others.

¬ß. 54. But it is not a very difficult Task to Whether Subjects, without the Con≈øent of their Sovereigns, may ≈øeparate them≈øelves from an Erroneous Religion? introduce a Reformation in Religion with the mutual Con≈øent of Sovereign and Subjects; ≈øo it may be que≈øtioned, whether Subjects may attempt a Reformation, when their Sovereigns, and the whole Clergy, or at lea≈øt the greate≈øt part of them, do not acknowledge their Error, but rather pretend to maintain it? In this ca≈øe, it is our Opinion that, provided the≈øe Errors ‚Ä¢ o touch the Fundamental
Points of our „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ Subjects, as by the Grace of God, and the ‚Ä¢ ight of his holy Spirit have attain ‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢ he true Knowledge, may ≈øeparate them≈øelves from the Communion of that Church without the con≈øent of their Sovereigns of the Clergy. For, every body being accountable to God for his Religion, and an≈øwerable for his own Soul, ‚Ä¢ ho≈øe Salvation cannot ab≈øolutely be committed to any Body el≈øe; and, a Chri≈øtian, in Matters of Faith, being not altogether to rely upon his Sovereign or the Clergy, (at lea≈øt no farther than their Doctrine is congruous with the holy Scripture.) It is undeniable, that Subjects may ≈øeparate them≈øelves from the Communion of that Church, which is pro≈øe≈ø≈øed by their Sovereign and Clergy, provided they can make it evidently appear, that ≈øuch a Church is infected with gro≈øs Abu≈øes, and dangerous Errors. For, the Church is a Colledge, who≈øe Members are not kept in Union by any Temporal Power, but by the Union of the Faith; and, who≈øoever relinqui≈øhes that, he di≈ø≈øolves the ≈øacred Tye of the Believers. Be≈øides that, it is not ab≈øolutely nece≈ø≈øary for our Salvation, that the Church be compo≈øed of a great Number, but the ≈øame may be obtained, either by a greater or le≈ø≈øer Number of the Believers. Neither can this Separation prove in the lea≈øt prejudicial to the Sovereign Authority, it being ≈øuppo≈øed, that tho≈øe who have ≈øeparated them≈øelves adhere to the true pure Doctrine of the Go≈øpel, free from all Poi≈øon, and Principles dangerous or prejudicial to the Government. For, civil Society was not in≈øtituted
for Religion's ≈øake; neither does the Church of Chri≈øt participate of the nature of a Temporal State; and therefore a Prince that embraces the Chri≈øtian Faith, does not thereby acquire an ab≈øolute Sovereignty over the Church or Mens Con≈øciences. So, that, if, notwith≈øtanding this Separation, the Subjects pay due Allegiance to their Prince in Temporal Affairs, there is no rea≈øon ≈øufficient which can oblige him to trouble them meerly upon the ≈øcore of their Con≈øciences. For, what lo≈øs is it to the Prince, whether his Subjects are of the ≈øame Religion with him≈øelf, or of unother? Or, (which was ≈øuppo≈øed before) whether they did maintain the ≈øame Errors, as he does? The ca≈øe indeed, would be quite different, if they ≈øhould endeavour to withdaw them≈øelves from their Allegiance, to ≈øet up a ≈øeparate Society without his Con≈øent; tho' it is undeniable, that there are ≈øome Ca≈øes of Nece≈ø≈øity, when this civil Tye or Allegiance may be di≈ø≈øolved, as for In≈øtance; when Subjects, for want of ≈øufficient Protection from their natural Prince, are ≈øo hardly pre≈ø≈øed upon by a more Potent Enemy, that they are forc'd to ≈øubmit to his Power. And granted the Power of Sovereigns in the Church to be much greater, than in effect it is, Subjects are neverthele≈øs bound to take care of their Souls, who≈øe Salvation is to be preferr'd before all other things, in regard of which they may ≈øeparate them≈øelves from an E≈øtabli≈øhed Religion, provided they are convinced of its Errors. For, that Subject who ≈øacrifices his Life for his Prince, does doubtle≈øs a glorious Action; but what Prince
can be ≈øo unrea≈øonable, as to expect that his Subjects ≈øhould Sacrifice their Souls to the Devil for his ≈øake. That Prince therefore who does trouble his faithful Subjects for no other rea≈øon, but becau≈øe they cannot conform to his Opinion (e≈øpecially if they can maintain theirs out of the Holy Scripture) commits an Act of Inju≈øtice; Nay, I cannot ≈øee how he can with Ju≈øtice force them out of his Territories. It is true, he may refu≈øe to receive Hereticks into his Dominions, unle≈øs it be for Rea≈øons of State; Neither can a true Believer take it ami≈øs, if he is not permitted to ≈øettle in a Commonwealth govern'd by Hereticks. For, the Right of Naturalization belongs to Sovereigns, which they may refu≈øe and give to whom they think it convenient. But, as it is certainly the greate≈øt Inju≈øtice in the World, to force an in-born Natural Subject, who has ≈øettled all his Fortunes in a Commonwealth, meerly for his Religion's ≈øake, without being convicted of his Error, out of his Native Country, to the great detriment and danger of him≈øelf and his Family. So, if a Subject inclines voluntarily to leave his Native Country, either to avoid the Frowns of his Prince, or the hatred of the Clergy and Common People, and to ≈øerve God with more freedom according to his own Con≈øcience, it ought not to be refu≈øed by his Sovereign. I remember there is a certain Proverb u≈øed among the Germans, viz. He that Commands the Country, Commands Religion. But this cannot be applied to the Princes of the Roman Catholick Religion, who cannot lay any Claim to it, it being evident
that the Popi≈øh Clergy do not allow any ≈øuch thing to the≈øe Princes; And, as to what concerns the Prote≈øtant E≈øtates of Germany, it cannot be denied, but that they made u≈øe of this Preten≈øion again≈øt the Emperor at the time of the Reformation, which however ought to be thus interpreted; That they denied the Emperor to have any Power of intermedling in the Affairs relating to their own Dominions, not, that only they claim'd it as belonging to the Rights of Sovereignty to impo≈øe any Religion, tho' never ≈øo fal≈øe, upon their Subjects; notwith≈øtanding all which, there are not wanting Examples, that Princes have acted conformable to this Proverb with their Subjects. A Prince, who troubles his faithful Subjects meerly upon the ≈øcore of Religion, commits a gro≈øs Error; no Chri≈øtian Prince being obliged to propagate his Religion by forcible means; provided his Subjects ≈øtand firm to their Allegiance to him, he being not an≈øwerable in particular for their Religion. It cannot be taken notice of without a≈øtoni≈øhment, how both in former times and our Age, ≈øome Princes, who were naturally not enclined to Cruelty, having in other re≈øpects given great Proofs of their Clemency, yet have been prevailed upon to rai≈øe the mo≈øt horrid Per≈øecutions again≈øt their Subjects, barely upon the ≈øcore of Religion. But it has been foretold in Holy Scripture, that this Fate ≈øhould attend the Chri≈øtian Church, when it is ≈øaid, That Mighty Kings upon Earth ≈øhould commit Rev. 18. 3. Whoredom with the Whore of Babylon. And, who is ignorant that Gallants will often commit
the mo≈øt barbarous Acts, meerly to plea≈øe their Harlots? All true Chri≈øtians therefore ought couragiou≈øly to oppo≈øe the Threats and Attempts of this Bea≈øt, committing the re≈øt to Divine Providence. And, as for ≈øuch Princes and States, as have ≈øhaken off the Yoke of Popi≈øh Slavery, if they ≈øeriou≈øly reflect, how their fellow-Prote≈øtants are per≈øecuted, and in what barbarous manner they are treated, will, que≈øtionle≈øs without my Advice, take ≈øuch mea≈øures, as may be mo≈øt convenient for to ≈øecure them≈øelves from ≈øo imminent a Danger.

div.head: The following ANIMADVERSIONS Made by the Author, upon ≈øome Pa≈ø≈øages of a Book, Entituled, A POLITICAL EPITOMY, Concerning the Power of Sovereigns in Eccle≈øia≈øtical Affairs. WRITTEN BY ADRIAN HOUTUYN, Having a very near Relation to the former TREATISE, it was thought ≈øit to In≈øert them here by way of APPENDIX.
div.p:
IT is a Que≈øtion of the greate≈øt moment, which, if rightly determined, tends to the Benefit of Mankind in general, viz. Unto whom, and under what Limitations the Power in Eccle≈øia≈øtical Affairs is to be a≈øcribed in the State? If the old Proverb, That tho≈øe who chu≈øe the middle way are commonly the mo≈øt ≈øucce≈øsful, has not lo≈øt its force, it may without que≈øtion, be mo≈øt properly applied in this Ca≈øe, where both Extreams are equally dangerous, ≈øince thereby the Con≈øciences of Subjects are left to the arbitrary di≈øpo≈øal, either of the Pope of Rome, or their Sovereigns.
There having not been wanting, both in the la≈øt and our Age, Men eminent for their Learning, who have with very ≈øolid Arguments oppo≈øed the Tyranny of the fir≈øt, it is but rea≈øonable for us, to take heed, that ≈øince we have e≈øcaped the danger of Scylla, we may not be ≈øwallowed up by Charybdis. For, as ≈øcarce any body that is in his right Sen≈øes can go about to deny, that the Sovereign Power ows its original either to God, or the general Con≈øent of the People; So it is a matter mutually advantageous both to the Prince and Subjects, to under≈øtand, how far this Power is limited in the State, that the fir≈øt may not tran≈øgre≈øs their due Bounds, and, in≈øtead of being Fathers of their Subjects, prove their mo≈øt dangerous Enemies. Adrian Houtuyn a Civilian in Holland, having in a Treati≈øe, called, A Political Epitomy, in≈øerted ≈øeveral A≈ø≈øertions tending to the latter of the≈øe two Extremes, and it having been ob≈øerved of late, that this Book has been recommended by ≈øome Doctors in the Law, to the great detriment of young Students; I thought it not ami≈øs to make ≈øome Animadver≈øions upon his LXIII, and following SECTIONS, which may ≈øerve as a Guide to the younger Sort, le≈øt they, under the Cloak of a≈ø≈øerting the Prerogatives of Sovereigns, may be mi≈ølead into the latter of the≈øe Extremes, and attribute that to the Prince, which God has re≈øerved as his own Prerogative, and thus, irrecoverably, play the Prodigal with their own Liberty and Property.

This Author ≈øpeaking concerning the Prerogative of Princes, Sect. LXIII, runs on thus:
He has an uncontroul'd Power over all External, Eccle≈øia≈øtical Affairs, which are not determined in the Holy Scripture. He alledges for a Rea≈øon, becau≈øe that Power is granted to Sovereigns at the ≈øame time when Subjects ≈øubmitted, them≈øelves and their Fortunes to their Di≈øpo≈øal. But it ought to be taken into Con≈øideration, that certain Matters belonging to the external Exerci≈øe of Religious Wor≈øhip have ≈øo ≈øtrict an Union with the internal Part, that, if the fir≈øt be not di≈øpo≈øed in a manner agreeable to this in≈øeparable Tye, the latter mu≈øt of nece≈ø≈øity undergo ≈øuch Alterations, as are incon≈øi≈øtent with its Nature. And, ≈øince Mr. Houtuyn do's not leave the internal Part to the Di≈øpo≈øal of Sovereigns, how can the exterior Wor≈øhip be ≈øubmitted to their meer Plea≈øure, con≈øidering this ≈øtrict Union betwixt them? Be≈øides this General Submi≈ø≈øion, he ≈øpeaks of admits of Limitation, in regard of that End, for which Civil Societies were In≈øtituted, which is, the mutual defence again≈øt Violences: From whence it is evident, that there are certain Matters, belonging to every private Per≈øon, derived from the State of natural Freedom, which were not ab≈øolutely left to the Di≈øpo≈øal of Sovereigns, at lea≈øt, no further than they were nece≈ø≈øary to obtain that End. Religion having not any relation to this End, it is not to be imagined, that Subjects did ≈øubmit their Religion to the arbitrary Plea≈øure of Sovereigns. And, it being unque≈øtionable, that Subjects may exerci≈øe certain Acts belonging to them by Vertue of an inherent Right, derived from the free State of Nature, and independent from
their Sovereigns, it may rationally be concluded, that, when Subjects did ≈øubmit them≈øelves, in Matters of Religion, to their Sovereigns, it was done with this Suppo≈øition, that both the Prince and Subjects were of one and the ≈øame Religion; and that the external Exerci≈øe of Religious Wor≈øhip was not left to the Di≈øpo≈øal of the fir≈øt, any further, than in ≈øuch Matters as are indifferent in regard of the internal Part of it. What is alledged concerning the the maintaining a good Order, and avoiding of Confu≈øion, it is to be ob≈øerved, that this is not the main End, for which Civil Societies were In≈øtituted, nor has it any relation to it, but only thus far, as it may be in≈øtrumental to maintain the Publick Tranquility.

As to N. 2. It is to be ob≈øerved, that, becau≈øe Prie≈øts have a dependance from the Civil Power in certain Re≈øpects belonging to its Juri≈ødiction, this does not involve Religion (con≈øidered as ≈øuch) under the ≈øame Subjection. The following words ought al≈øo to be taken notice of: A Chri≈øtian Prince commands over the Church, as being a Colledge, and repre≈øenting one ≈øingle Per≈øon in the Commonwealth. The Church, thus con≈øidered, is a Civil Society or Body Politick, founded upon the Publick Authority and Power, and ought to be regarded, as being in the ≈øame condition with other Colledges and Bodies Politick; and in this Sen≈øe a King is the Head of the Church in his Dominions. Whoever will con≈øider the real difference betwixt the Church and Commonwealth, mu≈øt needs find as many Errors, as there are words here. For, becau≈øe a Prince has the Sovereign Juri≈ødiction in a
Commonweath, con≈øi≈øting of Chri≈øtian Subjects; no inference is to be made, that therefore he may, in the ≈øame degree, exerci≈øe his Sovereignty in the Church, as in the Commonwealth, and that in the ≈øame Sen≈øe, he may be called, The Supream Head of the Church, as of the Commonwealth. 'Tis true, the Church is a Society, but not a Body Politick, founded upon the Publick Authority, but owes it Original to a higher Principle, having not, like other Colledges, its dependency from the State. What is alledged out of Titus, 2. 9. Colo≈ø. 3. 20, 22. Rom. 13. 3, 4. 1 Pet. 2. 14. is ≈øtrangely mi≈ørepre≈øented to evince, that Eccle≈øia≈øtical Matters are dependent from the ab≈øolute Plea≈øure of Sovereigns. What Follows might al≈øo very well de≈øerve ≈øome Animadver≈øions, if it were not beyond our ≈øcope at pre≈øent.

N. 13. It is a gro≈øs Error, That, as a Con≈øequence of this Sovereign Power in Eccle≈øia≈øtical Affairs, he attributes to them, the Titles of Pa≈øtors, Mini≈øters, Heralds of God, Bi≈øhops, Prie≈øts, and Apo≈øtles. Pray, with what Authority, and with what ≈øen≈øe? For, the Duty belonging to Sovereigns, which entitles them to the name of being the Guardians of both Tables of the Decalogue, and of being the Fo≈øter-Fathers and Defenders of the Church, is of a far different Nature from what he would in≈øinuate here. And, if it be not to be left to the ab≈øolute Judgment of the Clergy it ≈øelf, with exclu≈øion of the re≈øt of the Members of the Church, to determine in Eccle≈øia≈øtical Affairs, what is agreeable to the Word of God, how can this Judgment belong to the Sovereign
alone, without allowing a ≈øhare to the re≈øt of the Members of the Church?

The≈øe words in the ¬ß. LXIV. Each Sovereign may e≈øtabli≈øh what Religion he plea≈øes in his Dominions, ought not to be let pa≈øs by without a ≈øevere Correction. The Rea≈øon alledged is very frivolous: Becau≈øe all Publick and external Actions depend from the Publick Authority. Is this your A≈ø≈øertion, good Mr. Houtuyn, that Princes may impo≈øe what Religion they plea≈øe upon their Subjects, and by their ab≈øolute Authority make it the e≈øtabli≈øh'd Religion, with exclu≈øion to all others, who, if not complying, mu≈øt, for≈øooth, ≈øly the Country? What Religion they plea≈øe, do you ≈øay! the the Pagan, Fal≈øe, Fictious, or Super≈øtitious, it matters not which. From whence, pray, was this Power derived to Sovereigns? Not certainly from God, except you can ≈øhew us a Divine Authority for it. Not from the common con≈øent of tho≈øe that entred into Civil Societies; Commonwealths not being in≈øtituted for Religion's ≈øake, and of a later date; be≈øides, that ≈øuch a Power is not requi≈øite for the attaining that end, for which Civil Societies were e≈øtabli≈øh'd. Neither is it left to the bare plea≈øure of any Per≈øon, tho' con≈øidered as in the Natural ≈øtate of Freedom, to profe≈øs what Religion he plea≈øes: But, ≈øuppo≈øing it was, no Inference can be made from thence, that the ≈øame may be forc'd upon others. The di≈øtinction he makes betwixt the internal and external Religion, mu≈øt al≈øo be taken with a great deal of Circum≈øpection, le≈øt ≈øome People might per≈øwade them≈øelves, that it is indifferent
what Religion a Man profe≈ø≈øes in outward ≈øhew, provided he be ≈øatisfied as to the internal part of it. Furthermore, it is ab≈øolutely fal≈øe, that all Publick Actions, that is, every thing done in Publick in the Commonwealth, owes its Original to the Sovereign Power; there being ≈øeveral things to be done by Subjects in publick, depending meerly from that Liberty belonging to them in the Natural ≈øtate of Liberty, or from God's Command, or from a certain Power granted to them by God Almighty.

It is no le≈øs fal≈øe, That all exterior Actions depend from the Civil Authority; For, according to Mr. Houtuyn's Opinion, the Doctrine of Divinity, and the Confe≈ø≈øion of Faith, as comprehended in a certain form, are to be reckoned among tho≈øe exterior Actions. Mr. Houtuyn is much in the wrong, when he pretends to draw an Inference from thence; that, becau≈øe it belongs to Sovereigns to take care, that their Subjects may be well in≈øtructed concerning what Opinion they ought to have of God, as the E≈øtabli≈øher of Ju≈øtice; they therefore have a Right of di≈øpo≈øing (in an Arbitrary way) of revealed Religion, and to declare any Religion what≈øoever, which pretends to Revelation, the E≈øtabli≈øh'd Religion in the Commonwealth. It is a much gro≈ø≈øer Mi≈øtake yet, when he a≈ø≈øerts: That any Religion e≈øtabli≈øh'd in a State, tho' never ≈øo fal≈øe, contributes to the Publick Tranquility of that Commonwealth. It is po≈ø≈øible that a Religion defective in ≈øome Points, may neverthele≈øs lead People into the way of Salvation; but tho≈øe that contain fal≈øe
Doctrines of God and his Attributes, are incapable of producing that Effect. The Publick Tranquility, founded upon ≈øuch fal≈øe Opinions, will be very un≈øtable, and may with more ea≈øe, or at lea≈øt with the ≈øame conveniency be obtained by the true Doctrine; e≈øpecially if it be taken into con≈øideration, that, tho' it be po≈ø≈øible that ≈øuch Impo≈øtures may beguile the giddy-headed Multitude, they cannot always pa≈øs for currant among Men of a ≈øound Under≈øtanding: It is to be remembred, that the South≈øayers at Rome cannot forbear laughing, when they meet another of the ≈øame Profe≈ø≈øion. We mu≈øt beg Mr. Houtuyn's Pardon, if we que≈øtion his Authority, when he pretends to per≈øwade us: That Faith, which he is plea≈øed to call every ones private Religion, independent from any Temporal Power, will not be impaired by a Man's profe≈ø≈øing any other Religion, e≈øtabli≈øhed by the Sovereign Authority; and he leaves it to the di≈øcretion of tho≈øe Civil Governours, which of all Religions they will be plea≈øed to e≈øtabli≈øh in their Dominions, whether that of the Japone≈øes, of the Brachmans, Mahometans, Jews, or Chri≈øtians; and among all tho≈øe that pretend to the Chri≈øtian Name, ≈øuch a one as may be mo≈øt agreeable to their own Fancy. I much que≈øtion, whether he will meet with many Tools, that will take his Word for it. A great part of Chri≈øtendom did look upon it as a thing in≈øufferable, that the Pope of Rome ≈øhould ≈øet up for the great Arbitrator of Chri≈øtendom in matters relating to the Chri≈øtian Faith, tho' his Pretences did not reach further than to force
one Religion upon the World, which he knew was mo≈øt likely to turn to his own Advantage: But now it ≈øeems it has plea≈øed God, that Sovereigns ≈øhould be inve≈øted with a Power of e≈øtabli≈øhing any Religion at plea≈øure; and it being beyond que≈øtion, that there are ≈øeveral Religions which have not the lea≈øt relation to one another, they may, with the ≈øame Right, at ≈øeveral times, declare, ≈øeveral di≈øtinct Religions, nay, even tho≈øe that are quite oppo≈øite to one another, the e≈øtabli≈øh'd Religion, and neverthele≈øs every one of the≈øe mu≈øt be accepted, for≈øooth, as the true Religion.
